questions.text: Which nerve will be involved in the following finding on rest?
questions.solution:
The image depicts "Ulnar Claw Hand," which occurs due to ulnar nerve injury. This deformity is characterized by:

  • Hyperextension at the MCP joints
  • Flexion at the PIP and DIP joints
  • More pronounced in the 4th and 5th fingers

 

Deformities in ulnar nerve injury:

Partial claw hand:
  • Clawing: Hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of interphalangeal joints.
  • Clawing is seen in 2 medial fingers only.
  • Seen in pure ulnar nerve injury.
  • Also known as the true claw hand.

Complete claw hand:
  • Clawing of all 4 fingers.
  • Seen in combined median + ulnar nerve palsy

Tardy ulnar nerve palsy:
  • Slow-onset (over years) ulnar nerve palsy.
  • Seen with cubitus valgus deformity seen in lateral epicondyle humerus fracture.

Other deformities:
  • Wasting of hypothenar muscles & intrinsic muscles of the hand.
  • Hollow inter-metacarpal spaces in hand.

 

Ulnar paradox:

  • The higher the lesion, the less severe the deformity.
  • Reason: Long finger flexors are paralyzed and loss of finger flexion makes the deformity less obvious.

Treatment of Ulnar claw hand:

Static procedure (removal)
  • Zancolli Lasso procedure

Dynamic procedures (tendon transfer)
  • Modified Bunnel technique
  • Brand’s operation
  • Fowler’s operation

 

Median nerve (Option B):

  • Injury causes "Hand of Benediction" (inability to flex the 2nd and 3rd digits when attempting to make a fist).
  • Loss of thumb opposition (ape hand deformity) in severe cases.

Musculocutaneous nerve (Option C):

 

  • Primarily affects elbow flexion (biceps, brachialis).
  • No significant hand deformities.

None (Option D):

  • Incorrect, as this is a clear case of ulnar nerve injury.

questions.text: In which of the following nerve injuries is the instrument shown below used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Radial nerve

Explanation:

Image displayed is Dynamic Cock-up wrist splint used in management of Radial nerve palsy causing Wrist drop.

 

 

Radial nerve management:

Type of Injury
  • Treatment

Open Injuries
  • Immediate exploration and nerve repair or grafting

Closed Injuries
  • Wait 12 weeks for recovery before exploring
  • Use EMG if no improvement; if denervation is detected, perform nerve exploration and repair or grafting

Fractures of Humerus
  • Assess for nerve injury on admission
  • If the injury appears post-manipulation or internal fixation, explore and repair or graft immediately

Recovery Management
  • Perform passive hand movements
  • Splint the wrist in extension-cock up splint:

Long-term Disability
  • Tendon transfers: pronator teres to short radial extensor, flexor carpi radialis or ulnaris to finger extensors, palmaris longus to thumb abductor

 

Incorrect options:

Median nerve (Option B): Median nerve injury can lead to Carpal tunnel syndrome. Rest + Analgesics are the preferred management.

Ulnar nerve (Option C): Knuckle bender splint is used in the management of ulnar nerve injury.

Volkmann's ischemic contracture (Option D): Volkman splint or Turn buckle splint is used in the management.

questions.text: In the orthopedics outpatient department, a female patient is presenting with difficulty sleeping at night due to experiencing numbness and tingling in the outer three digits of their hand. The symptoms improve when the patient hangs their arms from the bed. Which of the following choices accurately identifies the patient's condition and the test employed to evaluate it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Carpal tunnel syndrome, Durkan's test

Explanation:

Tingling and numbness of fingers, with symptoms worsening at night is suggestive of Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). The most reliable clinical test to diagnose CTS is the Durkan test.

 

Carpal tunnel syndrome:

Definition
  • Compression of the median nerve as it passes through the carpal tunnel in the wrist

Symptoms
  • Numbness, tingling in thumb, index, and middle fingers
  • Pain in hand and wrist, Weakness in grip
  • Symptoms often worse at night and improve during the day.
  • Advanced cases may lead to hand weakness, clumsiness, and muscle atrophy.

Structures Affected
  • Median Nerve: Compressed within the carpal tunnel, leading to symptoms and signs.
  • Flexor Tendons: The nine flexor tendons passing through the carpal tunnel can become inflamed, further compressing the median nerve.

Structures Spared
  • Thenar Eminence: Sensory loss generally spares this area because its nerve (palmar sensory cutaneous nerve) bypasses the carpal tunnel.

Clinical Signs
  • Weakness: Notable weakness in thumb abduction and opposition.
  • Atrophy: Possible atrophy of the thenar eminence in advanced cases.
  • Sensory Loss: Loss typically affects the median nerve distribution (thumb, index, middle, and radial half of the fourth digit).

Causes
  • Idiopathic- commonest cause
  • Inflammatory causes- Rheumatoid arthritis, wrist osteoarthritis
  • Post-traumatic causes- Bone thickening after a Colles' fracture
  • Endocrine causes- Myxoedema, Acromegaly

Diagnostic Tests
  • Nerve Conduction Studies (NCS) - primary diagnostic test
  • Electromyography (EMG)
  • Phalen Test: Positive if pain/paresthesias arise during wrist flexion.
  • Tinel Test: Positive if tapping over the carpal tunnel elicits symptoms.
  • Durkan test: Direct compression on Median nerve for 30 seconds. More specific than the Phalen/Tinel test.

Treatment
  • Conservative: Wrist splinting, NSAIDs, activity modification
  • Corticosteroid injections
  • Surgical: Carpal tunnel release (for severe or refractory cases)

Guyon’s canal syndrome and Froment’s test (Option A):

  • Refers to involvement of the Ulnar side of the wrist leading to compression of Ulnar nerve.
  • Froment’s test: Used to test adductor pollicis muscle (supplied by Ulnar nerve).

Correct Answer: B) Cock-up splint

Incorrect Options:

Wrist splint (Option A): Wrist splints are widely used during post operative and post reduction period to reduce the pain and promote proper healing. The two conditions where a wrist splint is indicated are carpal tunnel syndrome and osteoarthritis (OA).

Dynamic finger splint (Option D): This splint is spring loaded and is used to provide stretch to those joints with reduced range of motion due to immobilization. It is done mainly after tendon and ligament injury, surgical repair etc.

questions.text: While examining a patient with a right forearm fracture, you ask him to make a fist. The following finding is noted during this procedure. What is the sign called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pointing index sign

Explanation:

The image in the question shows the Pointing Index sign seen in Median Nerve injury.

Clinical tests for Median nerve:

Test

Muscle tested and action

Pen test:
  • Muscle: Abductor pollicis brevis
  • Action: Abduction of thumb

Oschner clasp test:
  • Muscle: Flexor digitorum superficialis & flexor digitorum profundus
  • Action: Flexion of lateral 2 digits
  • Pointing index sign seen.

Thumb opposition:
  • Muscle: Opponens pollcis
  • Action: Opposition of thumb
  • O-sign is seen in normal patients

 

Treatment of median nerve palsy:

  • Conservative management mainly.
  • If not recovered, nerve repair is done by
    • High median nerve palsy (above elbow): 9 months
    • Low median nerve palsy (distal forearm): 12 months

 

Incorrect Options:

Froment’s sign (Option A): This sign is used to test function of Adductor Pollicis muscle specifically used to test ulnar nerve palsy. The patient will be asked to hold a piece of paper in between thumb and index finger and the examiner will attempt to pull the paper from the patient's grip.

 

Benediction sign (Option C): Patient when asked to make a fist, his/her middle and index fingers are extended. Hand of benediction (Preacher's hand) indicates clinical sign of peripheral neuropathy. It is specifically indicative of peripheral neuropathy affecting the muscles of the hand.

Policeman tip deformity (Option D): Also called as the porter's tip hand. It leads to abduction and lateral rotation of the shoulder.

questions.text: The patient experiences an inability to extend their wrist upon waking up after sleeping with their arm hanging over the back of a chair. This condition is caused by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Neuropraxia

Explanation:

Given clinical scenario is suggestive of Saturday night palsy, which is caused due to transient compression of radial nerve - known as Neuropraxia.

The Seddon classification is a system used to categorize peripheral nerve injuries based on the degree of damage to the nerve and its components.

Type

Description

Prognosis

Neurapraxia

(Grade I)
  • Temporary conduction block, myelin damage only.
  • No neuroma and no degeneration.
  • Recovery is complete within 6 weeks.

Axonotmesis

(Grade II)
  • Axonal damage, connective tissue intact.
  • Neuroma in continuity.
  • Degeneration: Proximally+distally.
  • Recovery can take up to months
  • Complete recovery may not occur.
  • Motor march present

Neurotmesis

(Grade III)
  • Complete nerve disruption.
  • End or side neuroma.
  • Degeneration: Proximally+distally.
  • Spontaneous recovery never occurs.
  • Repair is required (poor recovery)

Radial Nerve (Option B) palsy causes wrist drop due to paralysis of the extensor carpi radialis longus and extensor carpi radialis brevis. Compression of the radial nerve in the radial groove while putting a hand on a chair/clutch causes Saturday night/crutch palsy.

Median Nerve (Option C) palsy causes carpal tunnel syndrome (Compression neuropathy). Paralysis of opponens pollicis muscle causes ‘Ape thumb deformity’. Paralysis of the flexor digitorum superficialis and lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus of the index finger causes ‘Pointing index’.

Posterior Interosseous Nerve (Option D) injury causes loss of finger extension called finger drop. There is no sensory loss. The injury occurs at the head of the radius.

questions.solution:

Explanation:

  • The intact outer sheath and damaged inner axon are known as axonotmesis.
  • Tinel’s sign is positive and progressive. It is an axonal breakdown.
  • Recovery is not complete.
  • An injury to the peripheral nerve of one of the extremities of the body. The axons and their myelin sheath are damaged, but the endoneurium, perineurium and epineurium remain intact is defined as axonotmesis.

questions.text: A patient presents with the fracture shown in X-ray. Which nerve is most likely to be injured in this type of fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Radial nerve

Explanation:

The X-ray shows a spiral fracture of the midshaft humerus. This type of fracture is notoriously associated with injury to the radial nerve, which runs in close anatomical proximity to the bone at this specific location.

  • Anatomical Proximity: The radial nerve courses through the spiral groove (or radial groove) on the posterior aspect of the humerus. This close relationship makes it highly vulnerable to trauma during a fracture of the midshaft.
  • Clinical Presentation: An injury to the radial nerve typically presents with wrist drop, which is the inability to extend the wrist and fingers. This is a result of the nerve's innervation of the extensor muscles of the forearm. The incidence of radial nerve palsy in these fractures is approximately 10-20%.

Incorrect Options:

Median nerve (Option A) is located more medially in the arm and is rarely injured in a midshaft humeral fracture.

Ulnar nerve (Option C) runs along the medial epicondyle of the humerus and is most commonly injured in fractures of that region, not the midshaft.

Axillary nerve (Option D) is located more proximally, around the surgical neck of the humerus, and is most often injured in proximal humeral fractures or shoulder dislocations.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with numbness of both hands. He was asked to perform the test demonstrated below. What is the name of this test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C  - Roos test:

  • The Roos test, also called the "Elevated Arm Stress Test is used to evaluate thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS).
  • TOS is a condition characterized by the compression or irritation of the neurovascular structures in the thoracic outlet, which can lead to symptoms such as numbness, tingling, and weakness in the upper extremities.
  • During the Roos test, the patient is asked to actively elevate both arms to 90 degrees, flex the elbows to 90 degrees, and open and close their hands for approximately three minutes. If the patient experiences symptoms, such as numbness, tingling, or the inability to maintain the position due to pain or weakness, it may indicate a positive Roos test, suggesting the presence of TOS.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Adson's Test:

  • Adson's test is another test used to evaluate TOS. It involves checking the radial pulse while the patient rotates their head and extends their neck. This test is not demonstrated in the scenario.

Option B - Pemberton Test:

  • The Pemberton test is used to assess for thoracic outlet syndrome caused by the compression of structures between the clavicle and the first rib. It involves raising both arms above the head (180 degrees anterior flexion at the shoulder) while monitoring for symptoms. Unlike the Roos test, it does not involve pumping the fists.

 

Option D - Wright Test:

  • The Wright test, also known as the Hyperabduction Test, is a clinical examination used to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS). TOS is a condition characterized by compression of the neurovascular bundle (nerves, arteries, and veins) as it passes through the thoracic outlet. The Wright test specifically assesses for compression of the subclavian artery and the brachial plexus by the pectoralis minor muscle.
